notesStmt.note: Laurentius Franguellus: inscribed with his name, 1525 (folio 322v); see 78. Fra Luigi da Bologna Maggio, a converted Jew working for the Inquisition as censor (active approximately 1590-1609): inscribed with his name, 1599 (folio 322v); see 104.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: The commentary of Naḥmanides (Moshe ben Naḥman aka Ramban) on the Pentateuch.

collation.p: 27 quires of 12 leaves each. Quires marked with Hebrew letters and an abbreviation ב"ה on the right-hand upper corner of the first page. The Hebrew signatures are omitted in the latter portion of the manuscript.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Sefardi semi-cursive script, unpunctuated. Probably of 15th century.

binding.p: Post-1600; with Harleian coat of arms on both covers.

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
